turns.content: How have trade agreements affected the fishing industry in Nova Scotia, Canada?

Trade agreements have had both positive and negative effects on the fishing industry in Nova Scotia, Canada. 

On one hand, trade agreements such as the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) have opened up new markets for Nova Scotia's seafood exports, increasing demand and revenue for the fishing industry. For example, the CPTPP has eliminated tariffs on Canadian seafood exports to countries such as Japan and Vietnam, which are important markets for Nova Scotia's lobster and snow crab industries.

However, trade agreements have also led to increased competition from foreign fishing fleets and imports, which can threaten the sustainability of Nova Scotia's fisheries. For instance, the Canada-European Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) has resulted in increased competition from European seafood imports, which can be produced more cheaply than Canadian seafood products due to different labour and environmental standards.

Furthermore, trade agreements that prioritize investor rights can limit the ability of governments to regulate fisheries and protect marine ecosystems. For example, the Investor-State Dispute Settlement mechanism in NAFTA has been used by foreign investors to challenge Canadian fisheries policies and regulations.

Overall, while trade agreements have provided opportunities for Nova Scotia's fishing industry to expand its export markets, they have also brought new challenges that require careful management to ensure the long-term sustainability of the province's fisheries.
